repnme.cdata!:
Romania - First Programmatic Adjustment
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Programmatic
            Adjustment Loan (PAL1) Project for Romania were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was low or negligible, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the strong
            leadership by the Prime Minister's Chancellery was
            crucial for the success of the PAL1, but with hindsight more
            attention can have also been paid to strengthening capacity
            in the other parts of the Government. Such stronger
            capacity, and a revamped public administration, can have
            helped sustain the momentum on reforms even after the
            strategic goal of European Union (EU) accession was met and
            after the new government came to power. As with other
            middle-income countries with access to capital markets or EU
            resources, being flexible is important. This lesson will be
            of particular importance for the World Bank's
            engagement with the countries of the western Balkans. For
            these countries, as prospects of EU accession firm, EU funds
            will increase and private foreign capital strengthen,
            building on rising investor confidence.

9718279.trustfund:
TF021395-PHRD-FINANCIAL TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE,TF025553-PHRD-ROMANIA PSAL II PROJECT,TF026451-PHRD-ROMANIA: PUBLIC
            ADMINISTRATION REFORM PROJECT,TF027905-STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT LOAN (SAL),TF030428-CANADIAN CTF FOR CENTRAL AND
            EASTERN EUROPE FY04 - ECA GENERAL,TF040731-EUROPE & CENTRAL ASIA:

9718279.majtheme: Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development,Rule of law

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the First Programmatic
            Adjustment Loan for Romania was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was satisfactory, the institutional
            development impact was satisfactory, the Bank performance
            was highly satisfactory, and the borrower performance was
            satisfactory. The findings and implications indicate that
            the election in the fall of 2004 following the PAL 1 board
            approval was seen as a potential risk, as the outcome was
            not certain and there could have been some backtracking or
            even rejection of reform agreements. There appears to be a
            modest breakthrough on decentralization with detailed
            agreement reached between the Ministry of Public Finance and
            the Ministry of Interior on the process and timetable for
            preparing new legislation on intergovernmental fiscal
            relations. The IMF has had a series of SBA agreements with
            the authorities and there has been considerable overlap
            particularly in structural areas.

5209067.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Rule of law,Public sector governance

repnme.cdata!:
Romania - First Programmatic Adjustment
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This Programmatic Adjustment Loan
            Project for Romania is the first of a series of three PALs
            designed to support the Government's reform program
            over the period to 2007. The PAL program reflects the
            Government's overarching objectives of establishing
            solid economic growth, reducing poverty and joining the
            European Union. These objectives will be addressed by
            focusing on five key, cross-cutting themes: establishing
            public sector accountability; instilling financial
            discipline; instituting regulatory reforms; following good
            social and environment risk management practices; and
            ensuring property rights. In addition, the PAL provides
            continuity with previous adjustment operations b y ensuring
            sustained progress on the structural reforms begun under
            Private Sector Adjustment Loans 1 and 2, while at the same
            time introducing a new program of phased public sector and
            regulatory reforms that emphasizes institutional development
            and effective implementation. The program is divided into
            two parts. The first part focuses on reforming core public
            sector institutions and processes. The second targets the
            public- private interface and regulation of markets.
